questions.text: A 29-year-old woman comes to the OPD due to depression. Since breaking up with her boyfriend last month, she has been extremely sad and has difficulty getting out of bed. She describes sleeping 16 hours a day, increased appetite, a 4.5-kg weight gain, low energy, decreased concentration, and loss of interest in socializing with her friends and family. The patient had 2 similar episodes at age 23 and 27. She also describes brief periods in the past, lasting several days, when she was uncharacteristically confident and optimistic, successfully juggled 3 part-time jobs, and felt well rested and energetic despite sleeping only 3-4 hours a night. What is the likely diagnosis?

A 2-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his mother, who is concerned about his language development. She says, "I know that children speak at different ages and he is still young, but I am concerned that his speech isn't progressing and that he needs to interact with other children more. His day care teacher says that he is shy and sits in a corner playing with his favorite truck. We have also been busy with a recent move and have not given him as much attention, which doesn't help. The patient's birth history, medical history, and audiology screening are unremarkable. In the examination room, the patient sits in a corner, avoiding eye contact with the doctor. He does not respond to his name. He makes occasional grunting sounds but says no fully formed words. When his mother tries to take his truck away, he begins screaming and pulls it back. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

questions.text: An 18-year-old male presented with limp. X-ray of the pelvis was taken. What could be the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Fibrous dysplasia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Paget's disease is unlikely due to the patient's young age. Multiple myeloma is unlikely because it's very rare in young individuals and typically presents with systemic symptoms. Osteopoikilosis is unlikely as it is asymptomatic and would not cause limping. Fibrous dysplasia is the most likely diagnosis due to its characteristic appearance on X-ray and its association with bone pain, deformities, and limping in young individuals.
  • ➤ Paget's disease is unlikely due to the patient's young age.
  • ➤ Multiple myeloma is unlikely because it's very rare in young individuals and typically presents with systemic symptoms.
  • ➤ Osteopoikilosis is unlikely as it is asymptomatic and would not cause limping.
  • ➤ Fibrous dysplasia is the most likely diagnosis due to its characteristic appearance on X-ray and its association with bone pain, deformities, and limping in young individuals.

questions.text: Which one of the following amino acids is most likely to be found in the transmembrane region of a protein?
questions.explanation:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Amino acids with hydrophobic side chains, such as leucine, isoleucine, valine, and phenylalanine, are typically found in the transmembrane regions of membrane proteins. questions.text: A study reports a P-value of 0.03 and declares the results statistically significant with a significance level (α) set at 0.05. Which of the following statements is true based on this information?

options.label: A
options.text: A Type I error has occurred because the null hypothesis is rejected with a P-value less than α.

options.label: B
options.text: The P-value is greater than the significance level, meaning the null hypothesis should be rejected.

options.label: C
options.text: The Type II error rate is at its maximum, indicating no significant difference.

options.label: D
options.text: The P-value is less than α, so the null hypothesis is rejected, and the result is statistically significant.

questions.correct_answer: D. The P-value is less than α, so the null hypothesis is rejected, and the result is statistically significant.
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ A P-value less than α indicates that the result is statistically significant, meaning the null hypothesis is rejected.
  • ➤ A P-value less than α indicates that the result is statistically significant, meaning the null hypothesis is rejected.

questions.text: A 33-year-old man, Rajesh from Mumbai, visits the clinic for routine follow-up after undergoing pneumatic dilation for esophageal achalasia. He reports significant improvement in dysphagia and nocturnal regurgitation. His medical history includes borderline hypertension and an anxiety disorder. He previously smoked (5 pack-years) and has a family history of Sjögren’s disease and lymphoma. He is currently taking omeprazole and clonazepam. Educational Objective:

questions.text: Match the Following: Components of Cell Membrane and Their Functions Column A (Components of cell Membrane) Phosphatidylcholine Cardiolipin Cholesterol Glycolipids Column B (Functions) Prevents RBC hemolysis and is abundant in the CNS Exclusive to the human heart in mitochondria and linked to Syphilis Maintains membrane fluidity and acts as a fluidity buffer Major component of surfactant
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Phosphatidylcholine is the major component of surfactant, essential for reducing surface tension in alveoli. Cardiolipin is exclusive to the human heart in mitochondria and is implicated in Syphilis (anticardiolipin antibodies). Cholesterol maintains membrane fluidity and acts as a fluidity buffer, modulating the rigidity of the lipid bilayer. Glycolipids , including cerebrosides and gangliosides, are abundant in the CNS and GIT, respectively, and help in preventing hemolysis.
  • ➤ Phosphatidylcholine is the major component of surfactant, essential for reducing surface tension in alveoli.
  • ➤ Phosphatidylcholine
  • ➤ Cardiolipin is exclusive to the human heart in mitochondria and is implicated in Syphilis (anticardiolipin antibodies).
  • ➤ Cardiolipin
  • ➤ Cholesterol maintains membrane fluidity and acts as a fluidity buffer, modulating the rigidity of the lipid bilayer.
  • ➤ Cholesterol
  • ➤ Glycolipids , including cerebrosides and gangliosides, are abundant in the CNS and GIT, respectively, and help in preventing hemolysis.
  • ➤ Glycolipids

questions.text: After a myocardial infarction (MI), staining was done using Triphenyl Tetrazolium Chloride (TTC) Most myocardial tissue got stained in brick red color, while some tissue remained pale. What is the minimum survival time required post MI for this color change to appear? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 2-3 hours

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • The Triphenyl Tetrazolium Chloride (TTC) test is used to detect early myocardial infarction (MI) by staining viable cardiac tissue.
  • • The minimum survival time required Post MI is generally around 12 hours for any gross changes in the heart to be visible. The minimum survival time required Post MI is generally around 6 hours for any microscopic changes in the heart to be visible.
  • • The minimum survival time required Post MI is generally around 12 hours for any gross changes in the heart to be visible.
  • • The minimum survival time required Post MI is generally around 6 hours for any microscopic changes in the heart to be visible.
  • • However, with the use of TTC staining , gross changes in the heart can be observed as early as 2-3 hours post-MI.
  • • with the use of TTC staining
  • • In normal tissue , mitochondrial enzymes such as dehydrogenases are present, which reduce TTC, resulting in a brick-red color. In infarcted tissue , the infarcted area remains pale due to the absence of these mitochondrial enzymes, which are affected by the lack of blood supply. Complete mitochondrial enzyme death typically requires at least 2-3 hours of survival time, post-MI.
  • • In normal tissue , mitochondrial enzymes such as dehydrogenases are present, which reduce TTC, resulting in a brick-red color.
  • • normal tissue
  • • In infarcted tissue , the infarcted area remains pale due to the absence of these mitochondrial enzymes, which are affected by the lack of blood supply.
  • • infarcted tissue
  • • Complete mitochondrial enzyme death typically requires at least 2-3 hours of survival time, post-MI.
  • • Complete mitochondrial enzyme death
  • • Other Option :
  • • Other Option
  • • Option A. 1 hour: Incorrect. The TTC reaction typically requires at least 2-3 hours of survival time after MI for a clear distinction between infarcted and normal tissue to be visible.
  • • Option A. 1 hour: Incorrect.
  • • at least 2-3 hours
  • • Option C. 6-12 hours: Incorrect. While TTC can detect MI after 2-3 hours, the question specifically asks about the minimum time , not a broader window.
  • • Option C. 6-12 hours: Incorrect.
  • • minimum time
  • • Option D. > 24 hours: Incorrect. The TTC test can detect MI much earlier than 24 hours. The question is asking about the minimum time needed for the color change to appear.
  • • Option D. > 24 hours: Incorrect.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The TTC test is used to detect early MI. A brick-red color appears in viable myocardium, while the infarcted area remains pale after 2-3 hours post-MI.
  • ➤ brick-red color
  • ➤ 2-3 hours
  • ➤ Note that some sources suggest a minimum survival time of 4 hours for TTC positivity instead of 2-3 hours.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with progressive dysphagia that is more pronounced for liquids than solids. He reports occasional regurgitation of undigested food and has significant weight loss over the past few months. A barium swallow study is performed. Which radiological sign is most likely to be observed? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Rat-tail sign

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The clinical presentation strongly suggests achalasia cardia, a primary motility disorder of the esophagus.
  • • Dysphagia more pronounced for liquids than solids (characteristic of achalasia) The pattern is explained by the pathophysiology: liquids lack the mass and gravity effect to push through the non-relaxing lower esophageal sphincter, while solids can generate more pressure to pass through Regurgitation of undigested food Weight loss due to feeding difficulties The bird beak sign, showing a smooth, symmetrical tapering of the distal esophagus, is the classic radiological finding in achalasia on barium swallow. The rat tail sign, often used for carcinoma esophagus has also been described for achalasia.
  • • Dysphagia more pronounced for liquids than solids (characteristic of achalasia)
  • • The pattern is explained by the pathophysiology: liquids lack the mass and gravity effect to push through the non-relaxing lower esophageal sphincter, while solids can generate more pressure to pass through
  • • Regurgitation of undigested food
  • • Weight loss due to feeding difficulties
  • • The bird beak sign, showing a smooth, symmetrical tapering of the distal esophagus, is the classic radiological finding in achalasia on barium swallow.
  • • The rat tail sign, often used for carcinoma esophagus has also been described for achalasia.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Corkscrew esophagus : This appearance is seen in diffuse esophageal spasm, a different motility disorder with intermittent dysphagia.
  • • Option A. Corkscrew esophagus
  • • Option B. Apple-core lesion: This is typically seen in colonic carcinoma, appearing as a symmetric narrowing with overhanging edges. It's not associated with esophageal disorders.
  • • Option B. Apple-core lesion:
  • • Option C. String sign: This is typically seen in CHPS in the pylorus and TB and Chron’s disease in the ileum and represents narrowing.
  • • Option C. String sign:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In achalasia, dysphagia is characteristically worse for liquids than solids due to the underlying motility disorder affecting lower esophageal sphincter relaxation, with bird beak sign and rat tail sign being the characteristic radiological finding on barium swallow.

A 22-year-old man, diagnosed with Crohn’s disease, presents with persistent diarrhea for the past 3 months following ileal resection for small-bowel obstruction. He reports 4-5 loose bowel movements daily, significantly disrupting his daily activities and studies. He denies fever, abdominal pain, vomiting, or weight loss. He had a perianal abscess treated with metronidazole 7 months ago. Physical examination is unremarkable, apart from a well-healed abdominal scar. Laboratory findings: Mild anemia (Hb: 12.0 g/dL) Hypokalemia (K+: 3.4 mEq/L) Normal ESR (10 mm/h) Normal B12 levels Which of the following is most likely to improve his symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Cholestyramine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Bile acid malabsorption is a common cause of chronic diarrhea following ileal resection, as the terminal ileum plays a crucial role in bile salt reabsorption. Excess bile acids in the colon lead to secretory diarrhea, which can significantly impact daily life. Cholestyramine, a bile acid sequestrant, effectively binds bile acids and alleviates symptoms. Early recognition and appropriate management are essential to improving quality of life in post-resection patients.
  • ➤ Bile acid malabsorption is a common cause of chronic diarrhea following ileal resection, as the terminal ileum plays a crucial role in bile salt reabsorption.
